SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and dizziness for about five weeks. He attributes this to the change in seasons and increased activity due to home renovations. He also reports feeling bloated occasionally. The patient has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure regularly. However, his diet has been off due to the kitchen renovation, leading to eating out more often.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Endorses slight cramps that resolve after about an hour.
• Respiratory: Positive for a slight cough. Endorses shortness of breath during exertion.
• Gastrointestinal: Positive for occasional bloating. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Shows fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any significant weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure appears to be well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She denies any other injuries. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a nose job. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress and flexion of the knee. Normal sensation. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her into a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to take every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning. He felt a pop in his lower back and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. The pain has been persistent since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but they did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain. Endorses tingling in right toes.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.
• General: Denies fever or chills.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of the back reveals pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue to ice the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been compliant with metformin, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure readings have been running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been monitoring his knee and managing his osteoarthritis well.
• Medical Treatment: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well managed and maintained.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. He reports that his blood pressure has been mostly okay.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion, especially during humid weather. He runs 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Nasal congestion from pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: Well managed with Prozac.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is controlled, but patient admits to occasional noncompliance on weekends.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Status post lobectomy.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has no significant respiratory issues.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with surgeon needed.

Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right middle finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after a skiing accident. She has no other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no fractures.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up appointment. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia and associated symptoms.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also mentions worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and has had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with normal results.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occasional alcohol consumption (1-2 times per year).

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
Respiratory: Normal lung sounds.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia with associated symptoms.

PLAN

1. Continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption for the next 8-12 weeks.
2. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed.
3. If endoscopy and colonoscopy results are inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
4. Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.
5. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks of iron supplementation.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist.
2. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy.
3. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He has no prior history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently that he seems to be bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Adopted, family medical history unknown.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. No alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

RESULTS

Brain MRI with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to the patient's symptomatic presentation and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the assistance of the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The ER suspected a GI-related issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient reports that her chest pain and swallowing issues resolved approximately three days after her ER visit.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal (several years ago).

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history of GI problems.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain and bowel movement issues.
Positive for mild tenderness in the upper abdominal quadrants upon physical examination.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other significant findings.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal causes, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved, and she has been asymptomatic for the past three months.

PLAN

1. The patient will self-monitor her symptoms and call the office if she experiences any additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms.
2. If the patient experiences recurrent or worsening symptoms, she will be scheduled for an EGD to further evaluate her esophagus and stomach.
3. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female, former 34 and 3-week-old twin, with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She has a history of feeding difficulties, temperature regulation issues, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She is scheduled to start speech therapy in the next couple of weeks. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

The patient's geneticist mentioned that individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome may have kidney abnormalities, such as fused kidneys, and potential issues with their legs. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has approximately 8 to 10 wet diapers in a 24-hour period and is drinking well.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Feeding difficulties.
Temperature regulation issues.
Developmental delays.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the kidney ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up is needed. If there are abnormalities, determine next steps and schedule follow-up at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. The nurse will provide paperwork and instructions for the ultrasound. The doctor will call with the results and discuss any necessary next steps.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. She reports that her wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling and bruising on the right wrist.
Neurological: Reports slight tingling in fingers, but no significant numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
RR: 20 bpm

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is normal. No lower edema.
NEURO: Normal sensation. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation throughout. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively at first, with a brace for her right wrist. We will schedule surgery as soon as possible. In the meantime, the patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management. Post-surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for rehabilitation. The patient will follow up in a month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to continue icing her wrist and taking pain medication as prescribed. She should follow up in a month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she should contact the office immediately.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee during the fall and has been experiencing pain and swelling since then.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg Lisinopril.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort.
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's history of fall and physical exam findings suggest a medial collateral ligament strain.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times daily. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure remains elevated despite taking Lisinopril.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help improve diet and potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. The patient denies he has done any physical therapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap feeling unstable. The pain comes and goes quickly, and the patient denies any history of injury or trauma to the knee. The patient has not taken any medications for the pain, as it does not last long. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and participating in line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies any history of injury or trauma to the knee.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and make any necessary adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and difficulty swallowing for 4 days.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and diabetes. Received COVID-19 vaccine but not the booster.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works as a cashier in a supermarket. She enjoys drinking wine.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking lisinopril 20 mg daily, multi-vitamin, vitamin D, and metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever, chills, and profuse sweating.
HENT: Reports sore throat, dysphagia, tonsil swelling, and congestion.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal symptoms.

VITALS

Temperature: 100.4 degrees F.
Blood pressure: 132/80 mm Hg.
Heart rate: 84 BPM.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No pain to palpation of the frontal or maxillary sinuses.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Nose: Edema and erythema of the nasal turbinates noted bilaterally with associated clear discharge.
- Examination of Throat: Erythema and edema of the peritonsillar space with exudates present bilaterally. The uvula is midline.

Neck
- General Examination: No thyromegaly, but there is some cervical lymphadenopathy on the right side.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Coarse rhonchi at the bases that clear with cough.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

RESULTS

Rapid COVID-19 test performed today in office is negative.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Sore throat and difficulty swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has experienced sore throat, fever, chills, profuse sweating, and difficulty swallowing for 4 days. There is erythema and edema of the peritonsillar space with exudates present bilaterally as well as edema and erythema of her turbinates, bilaterally.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options today. I have stressed the importance of hydration.
- Medical Treatment: We will perform a rapid strep test today. If she is positive for strep, I will prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg 3 times a day for 10 days. Prescription for lidocaine swish and swallow provided for pain relief. Ibuprofen can also be taken for pain and fever relief.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient states her blood pressure fluctuates often. Her blood pressure today in office was 132/80 mm Hg.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options including increasing her lisinopril and diet modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Lipid panel ordered. Prescription for lisinopril 40 mg once a day is also provided.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient’s blood sugar fluctuates between 80 to 90 in the morning to 140 in the evening. She is already at 1000 mg of metformin twice a day, which she does take with meals.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of achieving a healthy lifestyle and what effects that can have on her diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: I have placed an order for a hemoglobin A1c.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during wintertime, which tend to linger. Family owns a donut shop. Recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections or diarrhea.

VITALS

No concerning findings.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neck
- Examination: No lymphadenopathy.

Abdominal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender.

RESULTS

Recent lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. Some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections, but this does not seem to be the case for the patient.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. We will order additional blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies. The patient was advised to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. If the patient requires blood products, they should inform the provider of their IgA deficiency.
- Medical Treatment: No specific treatment needed at this time. Will monitor for any changes in symptoms or infections.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of the elbow and sometimes radiates down into the forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 and has been causing difficulty in lifting and performing daily activities. The patient has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that he has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: Examination of the right elbow reveals pain to palpation over the medial epicondyle. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The following plan was recommended:

1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

The patient agreed to the plan, and the nurse will provide a sling for the patient.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: Not reported
Heart Rate: Not reported
Oxygen Saturation: Not reported

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting their sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding their diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Patient advised to weigh themselves daily and call if they gain 3 pounds in 2 days.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and making dietary modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. He has been experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and worsens when it occurs. He reports burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

GI: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
GU: Reports burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient should use the strainer when he urinates until the stone passes. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient should contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right foot non-healing ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister became unroofed, revealing thick, soft, and mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient's wife called their primary care doctor, who started him on antibiotics six days ago. The patient has experienced some chills and a fever of 99.7°F. The ulcer has turned black around the outside, and the patient has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. There is also a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot. The patient has been coughing and experiencing shortness of breath.

The patient is diabetic and has diabetic neuropathy. His blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His last A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked to Charlie's Bunion. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every three to four months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Fever of 99.7°F and chills.
Cardiovascular: Cramping in calf muscle.
Respiratory: Coughing and shortness of breath.
Skin: Right foot ulcer with black edges and red streak up the ankle and calf.
Neurological: Diabetic neuropathy.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Within normal range.
Heart rate: Within normal range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable pulses femorally and popliteal pulses present. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
RESPIRATORY: Coughing and shortness of breath.
SKIN: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and foul odor. No bony exposure.
NEUROLOGICAL: Diabetic neuropathy.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent poor blood sugar control
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed the following plan:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement today in the office.
3. Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on culture results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in seven days.
6. Follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management and maintaining A1c below 7.
7. Continue current antibiotic therapy and adjust based on culture results.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. Patient noticed a tick bite on the right knee over a week ago, with persistent burning sensation and discomfort. Patient denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled on lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled on metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever or chills.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain in joints.
Neurological: Denies dizziness or numbness.
Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4°F
Respiration: Normal

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the patella. Pain to palpation. Full range of motion.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash present over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite on the right knee, bull's-eye rash, and general malaise since the bite.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c to evaluate long-term blood sugar control. Per patient's request, order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
